name: Big Data
description:
Tom Rogers will be presenting on BIG DATA

Big Data is everywhere but what is this thing really?

Tom will be talking about what Big Data is and what are the basic concepts driving the Big Data phenomena. He will also be talking about Apache Hadoop and how it implements the Big Data Methodologies. If we have time, we will wrap up by briefly discussing the Internet of Things and how you can easily begin to play in the IoT sandbox.

name: ChicagoRuby Hack Night - Traveling Salesman Problem
description:
Come on out and hack!


We'll get together to work on a Ruby problem.¬†

All Rubyists are welcome, including beginners. Bring your
laptop with Ruby installed.¬†

Avant, our hosts, will provide food and drink.

After, feel free to post Github links to your solutions below!

This month, we'll work on implementing a solution to The Traveling Salesman problem. The prompt we will be using can be found here¬†- it includes some tests (using Minitest) that you can use to check your implementation. An alternate version of the tests written in RSpec are available here.

name: ChicagoRuby: BLUE1647 - So Many Single Board Computers
description:
So Many Single Board Computers

It started with the Raspberry Pi. And now there are so many (BeagleBone Black, Parallella, etc.) that one can barely keep count. How many single board computers are there? What are they good for?


This meeting will introduce you to single board computers. Several models will be available for you to explore, including Raspberry Pi, BeagleBone Black, Orange Pi, Banana Pi, Parallella, and Pine64.


Bring your own single board computer(s) if you like. We'll have extra HDMI monitors on hand so you can hook 'em up.


Agenda:


* 20 minutes: Intro to Single Board Computers. Why do they exist? Which ones are best for your work?


* Remainder of meeting: Hands-on with multiple single board computers. What are the "gotchas" and how do you work around them? When we put our heads together, problems are easier to solve.

ChicagoRuby is excited to expand to BLUE1647, a technology innovation center that includes software development and maker space. At ChicagoRuby: BLUE1647 we come together in an environment that fosters collaboration and creating. In keeping with that spirit we invite everyone to come meet new people, share ideas, learn new things, and build!


Let the group know what you’d like to take away from the meetings and what would be interesting to you. We are all students and teachers so feel free to share your knowledge and experiences with fellow Rubyists.

name: Team ([group])!! - Meetup Vs Meetup
description:
This is going to be the biggest collaboration event ever seen in the Meetup community of Melbourne, it's a one time¬†only event that we are pretty excited to be apart of!!


Fundamentally this event is really about bringing the Meetup community together and connecting with each-other like never¬†before.¬†This event is also your chance to give back to your group! You may or may not be aware that the organizers who run the¬†groups you love and enjoy so much not only have to financially support the group in order to keep it running, but can¬†also invest up to 40 hours a week organizing the events you love. Attending this event will give you the opportunity to¬†make a $5 (recommended) donation to your group. Every dollar will go towards financially supporting this group, aiding¬†the organizer/s with paying their Meetup fees and the administration costs that go with running these events.


What to expect?


Trivia will be the main ingredient of this event, but it will be more than just your average trivia night!¬†

*** Expect a fun and interactive evening, designed by leading Melbourne Meetup group organizers to cater specifically to a Meetup¬†audience. Expect a fun evening with good food, drinks and laughs. We will be encouraging interaction between the different groups¬†during the breaks and at the end.

There will be a professional quizmaster leading the processions in a light and entertaining manner.¬†

Tim is a comedian and trivia host based in Melbourne. He hosts various trivia nights throughout the city. With three years of trvia experience, his laid back style and easygoing attitude ensure the night is more about fun then fierce competition. You can also take joy in knowing that even if you come last, you're still smarter then the trivia host.


Food specials - ALL MEALS $20 - INCLUDES DRINK¬ß

o¬†Chicken parmigiana and chips

o¬†Beef burger and chips

o¬†Singapore noodles

o¬†Vegetarian risotto

o¬†Steak sandwich and chips

¬ß¬†All served with a pot of Carlton Draught, glass of house wine or sparkling wine

Each table will be between 5 and 15 people, but groups with more interest can fill multiple tables if need be. We expect¬†at least 10 teams of around 10 people per team based on the interest from other groups over the last few months of¬†putting this event together.

All groups are welcome! however in order to track RSVPs, and communicate with hosts, only registered Meetup groups can¬†attend. If you also run a Meetup group and would like to be involved in this event or future collaboration events¬†contact Steve on 0400 783 836 or complete registration on this link and you will be contacted soon:¬†http://goo.gl/forms/WCEEuBx2KD.¬†Registrations for new groups close on Easter Friday (03/04/2015)
how_to_find_us: Instructions for your members (Tables will have your group names on them)

name: ChicagoRuby: Elmhurst - How Do I Build... ?
description:
The "How Do I Build...?" format is somewhere between a hack night and a presentation.

The key question: "How do I build [X] in Ruby or Rails?" We might talk about the best shopping cart or calendar or whatever for Rails. We might talk about the best way to do database maintenance with Ruby, or the best tools for organizing Ruby or Rails development.

Every ChicagoRuby member is invited to drive. Let the group know what you want to do, what you've tried, and what would be interesting to you.¬†Let's put our heads together and create!

Lunch After the Meeting
After most meetings, we go to lunch at the Elmhurst Restaurant, roughly two blocks NW of the meeting venue. Address: 441 West Lake Street, Elmhurst, IL 60126. Join us!

name: Pitch + Catch
description:
Open to the public!

Pitch and Catch offers 25N members an opportunity to present their business plan, new idea, or sales pitch to an audience of mentors, advisors, entrepreneurs, and you!

Pitchers prepare a 5 minute presentation and engage in 20 minutes of feedback and questioning. 25N members gain insight into possible ways they can improve their businesses and gather real time feedback.

The audience learns a great deal from the presentations. There is much to learn every month from these dynamic and diverse entrepreneurs. We need you in our audience!

name: Lightning Talks: Editor Tricks Edition
description:
This month will be lightning talks with a focus on editor/IDE tricks. Contact Ryan or Micheal if you would like to give a talk ranging from 2 - 10 minutes and we will add you to the agenda.


Storyteller: Mark Mahoney
Storyteller is a tool which captures a lot of information from the editor and allow a programmer to recreate programming sessions. Then they can create a narrative that goes along with the played back code that can include text and images. The idea is that these narratives, or stories, are better than code comments for describing how and why the code evolved.


Atom for Vim Users: Ryan Gerry¬†
Ryan is a long time vim user who is currently using Atom as his main editor. He will walk through some tricks and make a case for why it might make sense to switch to Atom.

OSX Preview: Digital Document Swiss Army Knife: Ryan Gerry
The Preview application in OSX has many little known features that can make your life easier. Have you ever had to sign a legal document by first using the device from hell¬†just to have to scan it in again? Ryan will show you how to avoid all of that pain in addition to some other nifty tricks.

description: Fox Valley Drupal is offering an invitation for us to join them for a session on Using Git, GitHub & Bitbucket. While the focus of this session will be for Drupal Projects... the tools apply for any project using Git for version control. http://www.meetup.com/Fox-Valley-Drupal/events/228971819/

name: 3D in the Web with Virtual Reality and Native-centric Hybrid Development
description:
We have two exciting talk:¬†

Intro to 3D Modeling & 3D on the Web (With VR) by¬†Eric J Nesser (30min)


Description:¬†Modeling a realistic earth in Blender and then animating it on the web with ThreeJS, WebGL, and ES2015.


Based on my open source project here --
https://github.com/enesser/earth-webgl

Also a small section on getting it to work with virtual reality devices like the Google cardboard.

Native-centric Hybrid Development using Cordova & Ionic ¬†by¬†Torey Lomenda


Description:¬†Every tool has its purpose, and used the "right-way" Cordova can provide many benefits to the mobile developer. This talk will explore a "right-way" of combining native code with embedded Cordova web components to get a more optimized UX on a targeted native platform while maximizing reuse of cross-platform web components. This native-centric approach allows developers to make the best choice when evolving features for their mobile apps. This talk will focus on leveraging Cordova and the Ionic UI framework to seamlessly integrate web components on Android and IOS mobile platforms.

We are looking for speaker for future meetup:¬†Call for Speaker¬†

Schedule 6:00 - begin arriving and socialize

6:30 - presentation begins

Space, food and refreshments will be provided by Enova International.

name: April Hack Night!!!
description:
Code together, on anything!

This Meetup is different - there aren't any presentations, instead people just code together. Some like to check out Javascript, others take a look at a Rails class to refactor. There are PHP, iOS, Java, .NET developers, and others - whatever technology you're into is cool!

If you have a project to hack on, that's great but even just coming out for some great conversation is cool too. This is a very open group - really just a bunch of techies looking to geek out, bring your laptop and join us!!

Pizza is provided by Grid Connect. Bring your own drinks, beer encouraged!¬†üçª

name: Ignite - Monthly Meetup For Suburban Entrepreneurs
description:
Learning from others and learning on your own are equally important. ¬†Sprinkle a little accountability into the mix, and you have the perfect recipe to help ignite your process of validating and building an idea. ¬†This ideology has been used by myself and other members at the Elgin Technology Center for some time now, and we thought it was time to open it up to the public by creating a new meetup group called Ignite.¬†


Ignite is focused on providing education, collaboration, and most importantly holding entrepreneurs accountable so they can continue to make progress in validating and building meaningful solutions to problems.


Education

We will focus the first half of each meetup around a new startup topic. ¬†One week we might be discussing how to build a killer UVP (unique value proposition), and the next might be about ways to create a MVP (minimum viable product) for validation purposes.

Collaboration

One of the most important aspects of Ignite is collaboration. ¬†Are you struggling with something as you try to launch your startup? ¬†Do you have any interesting¬†“A-ha” moments you want to share with the group? ¬†We will dedicate plenty of time to help¬†each other¬†out in a collaborative setup.

Accountability

Holding yourself and / or co-founders accountable can be a very difficult task. ¬†We will wrap each meetup with a sprint meeting where Ignite entrepreneurs make goals to hit by the next meetup. ¬†Our goal is to provide you with a little extra motivation to take action and produce results that you can share with the team next month.

name: ChicagoRuby: Downtown - JavaScript for Rails Devs
description:
JavaScript for Rails Devs
Front end JavaScript is a swampland of buzzwords, leaky abstractions, and complicated toolchains. Fortunately, there are some simple techniques we can use to avoid the quagmire and build dynamic, modern user interfaces that solve human problems.

In this talk, the presenter will show you a technique for embedding JavaScript components inside of otherwise server rendered pages to create islands of interactivity. This can be done with your existing build system, adding nothing but 20KB of gzipped JavaScript and a dash of common sense.¬†


About the Presenter
Zach Briggs is a¬†JavaScript jockey at TableXI. He has spoken or taught workshops at RailsConf, CodeMash, Barcelona Ruby Conf, KalamazooX, and many more.

After most downtown meetings we head over to Elephant & Castle (185 N. Wabash) for refreshments & fellowship. Join us for a few minutes if you have time.

Please use your real name when you RSVP for downtown ChicagoRuby meetings. Reason: We are required to give a list of all attendees to the security desk prior to the meeting. If the name on your ID doesn't the match the name on the RSVP list, then Aon security will not let you in the building. Sorry for the inconvenience, but those are the rules of the Aon Building.

name: ChicagoRuby: Downtown -  A Rubyist's Journey into Bitcoin
description:
A Rubyist's Journey into Bitcoin
Bitcoin is the world's most popular digital cryptocurrency, with its own built-in scripting language. It's programmable money! This talk will introduce the fundamentals of Bitcoin, and and then demonstrate how Rubyists can interact with its peer-to-peer network, broadcast transactions, and even use its blockchain as a data store.

About the Presenter
Dave Hoover started learning Ruby in 2002, and using it in earnest in 2005 when Rails hit the scene. Dave was a partner at Obtiva, a Chicago-based, Ruby-focused dev shop that was acquired by Groupon in 2011. While at Obtiva, Dave used Ruby to build the first version ofmadmimi.com, as well as making some early contributions at Groupon. He published Apprenticeship Patterns in 2010, a guide for people wanting to improve themselves as software developers. In 2012, Dave joined Dev Bootcamp, and founded the Chicago location in 2013. Nowadays, Dave has returned to his roots, and is a freelance software developer. He mainly works from his family's home in Wheaton. In December 2015, Dave caught Bitcoin fever.


After most downtown meetings we head over to Elephant & Castle (185 N. Wabash) for refreshments & fellowship. Join us for a few minutes if you have time.

Please use your real name when you RSVP for downtown ChicagoRuby meetings. Reason: We are required to give a list of all attendees to the security desk prior to the meeting. If the name on your ID doesn't the match the name on the RSVP list, then Aon security will not let you in the building. Sorry for the inconvenience, but those are the rules of the Aon Building.

name: Ignite - Monthly Meetup For Suburban Entrepreneurs
description:
Learning from others and learning on your own are equally important. ¬†Sprinkle a little accountability into the mix, and you have the perfect recipe to help ignite your process of validating and building an idea. ¬†This ideology has been used by myself and other members at the Elgin Technology Center for some time now, and we thought it was time to open it up to the public by creating a new meetup group called Ignite.¬†


Ignite is focused on providing education, collaboration, and most importantly holding entrepreneurs accountable so they can continue to make progress in validating and building meaningful solutions to problems.


Education

We will focus the first half of each meetup around a new startup topic. ¬†One week we might be discussing how to build a killer UVP (unique value proposition), and the next might be about ways to create a MVP (minimum viable product) for validation purposes.

Collaboration

One of the most important aspects of Ignite is collaboration. ¬†Are you struggling with something as you try to launch your startup? ¬†Do you have any interesting¬†“A-ha” moments you want to share with the group? ¬†We will dedicate plenty of time to help¬†each other¬†out in a collaborative setup.

Accountability

Holding yourself and / or co-founders accountable can be a very difficult task. ¬†We will wrap each meetup with a sprint meeting where Ignite entrepreneurs make goals to hit by the next meetup. ¬†Our goal is to provide you with a little extra motivation to take action and produce results that you can share with the team next month.

name: Navigating Minecraft
description:
Confirmed Date has been set!¬†


Please update your RSVP if it will work out for your calendar.

Parents, wondering what this Minecraft thing is all about?¬†
Minecrafters, want to show your stuff?¬†
Newbes, learn all about it.

Minecraft is an “Open World” game played on a number of different platforms with over 21 million PC users alone. The game has no specific storyline or accomplishments, but allows players freedom to choose how they want to play. The PC version is written in Java and there is an extensive network of ‘Modders’ who write ‘mods’ or modifications to the game which are available free for download all over the internet.¬†


Robin Schroeder will be guiding us through the Minecraft maze:

• Brief History
• Introduction to the technical aspects of Minecraft
• Mods and Plugins
• Short Code tour of a Minecraft Mod
• Minecraft Servers for Multiplayer mode

Bring a laptop and $ for Pizza

Sorry, minors (under 18) must be accompanied by a parent or guardian, or authorized adult.

name: ChicagoRuby: Elmhurst - How Do I Build... ?
description:
The "How Do I Build...?" format is somewhere between a hack night and a presentation.

The key question: "How do I build [X] in Ruby or Rails?" We might talk about the best shopping cart or calendar or whatever for Rails. We might talk about the best way to do database maintenance with Ruby, or the best tools for organizing Ruby or Rails development.

Every ChicagoRuby member is invited to drive. Let the group know what you want to do, what you've tried, and what would be interesting to you. Let's put our heads together and create!

name: Ignite - Monthly Meetup For Suburban Entrepreneurs
description:
Learning from others and learning on your own are equally important. ¬†Sprinkle a little accountability into the mix, and you have the perfect recipe to help ignite your process of validating and building an idea. ¬†This ideology has been used by myself and other members at the Elgin Technology Center for some time now, and we thought it was time to open it up to the public by creating a new meetup group called Ignite.¬†


Ignite is focused on providing education, collaboration, and most importantly holding entrepreneurs accountable so they can continue to make progress in validating and building meaningful solutions to problems.


Education

We will focus the first half of each meetup around a new startup topic. ¬†One week we might be discussing how to build a killer UVP (unique value proposition), and the next might be about ways to create a MVP (minimum viable product) for validation purposes.

Collaboration

One of the most important aspects of Ignite is collaboration. ¬†Are you struggling with something as you try to launch your startup? ¬†Do you have any interesting¬†“A-ha” moments you want to share with the group? ¬†We will dedicate plenty of time to help¬†each other¬†out in a collaborative setup.

Accountability

Holding yourself and / or co-founders accountable can be a very difficult task. ¬†We will wrap each meetup with a sprint meeting where Ignite entrepreneurs make goals to hit by the next meetup. ¬†Our goal is to provide you with a little extra motivation to take action and produce results that you can share with the team next month.

Join us for lunch, conversation and networking this Friday. You can meet at ETC, 73 Riverside Drive, Elgin, by 11:45 on Friday and leave as a group to the restaurant of choice, or you can meet us there. Bring your smile and business cards and join us! Invite a friend or colleague too.


The restaurant for this Meet Up will be announcement about one week prior.

name: First Friday Tech Social

group.name: Fox.Build - Coworking, Hacking, Maker-Space in St. Charles

description: Rick and I started O'Beer Thirty on Fridays at 3:30 when we were at Rev3 in Naperville. We're taking the tradition to Fox.Build. Join us for a libation at 3:30PM on Friday or whenever you get off work. We'll be here until 7:00 when we hit a local bar or restaurant to grab some food.
how_to_find_us: We are upstairs from Discount Uniforms.

name: Free Coworking Day @ Fox.Build

group.name: Fox.Build - Coworking, Hacking, Maker-Space in St. Charles

description: Bring your laptop, ideas and projects. Come join us and check the place out. A word of warning though, if you are looking for beautiful architecture and serene offices, you probably want to go to the Regus down the street. We are a place where there's bound to be sawdust on the floors. Bring your headset and music, turn it on and do the thing you do the best. We have a fast internet connection, it's walking distance from from great restaurants and coffee shops and perfect for freelancing or people who are sick of the isolation of working from home. Call me if you want to talk about how we can support you and your business. 630-935-4363 Tim

description:
Come on out and hack! We'll get together to do a small Ruby project.

All Rubyists are welcome, including beginners. Bring your laptop with Ruby installed.

Avant, our hosts, will provide food and drink.

description:
Guests always welcome

name: ChicagoRuby: Elmhurst - How Do I Build... ?
description:
The "How Do I Build...?" format is somewhere between a hack night and a presentation.

The key question: "How do I build [X] in Ruby or Rails?" We might talk about the best shopping cart or calendar or whatever for Rails. We might talk about the best way to do database maintenance with Ruby, or the best tools for organizing Ruby or Rails development.

Every ChicagoRuby member is invited to drive. Let the group know what you want to do, what you've tried, and what would be interesting to you. Let's put our heads together and create!

Lunch After the Meeting
After most meetings, we go to lunch at the Elmhurst Restaurant, roughly two blocks NW of the meeting venue. Address: 441 West Lake Street, Elmhurst, IL 60126. Join us!

name: Pitch + Catch
description:
Open to the public!

Pitch and Catch offers 25N members an opportunity to present their business plan, new idea, or sales pitch to an audience of mentors, advisors, entrepreneurs, and you!

Pitchers prepare a 5 minute presentation and engage in 20 minutes of feedback and questioning. 25N members gain insight into possible ways they can improve their businesses and gather real time feedback.

The audience learns a great deal from the presentations. There is much to learn every month from these dynamic and diverse entrepreneurs. We need you in our audience!

description: Please contact the organizers if you are interested in presenting or suggesting a presentation.

name: ChicagoRuby: BLUE1647
description:
ChicagoRuby is excited to expand to BLUE1647, a technology innovation center that includes software development and maker space. At ChicagoRuby: BLUE1647 we come together in an environment that fosters collaboration and creating. In keeping with that spirit we invite everyone to come meet new people, share ideas, learn new things, and build!

Let the group know what you’d like to take away from the meetings and what would be interesting to you. We are all students and teachers so feel free to share your knowledge and experiences with fellow Rubyists.

name: Ignite - Monthly Meetup For Suburban Entrepreneurs
description:
Learning from others and learning on your own are equally important. ¬†Sprinkle a little accountability into the mix, and you have the perfect recipe to help ignite your process of validating and building an idea. ¬†This ideology has been used by myself and other members at the Elgin Technology Center for some time now, and we thought it was time to open it up to the public by creating a new meetup group called Ignite.¬†


Ignite is focused on providing education, collaboration, and most importantly holding entrepreneurs accountable so they can continue to make progress in validating and building meaningful solutions to problems.


Education

We will focus the first half of each meetup around a new startup topic. ¬†One week we might be discussing how to build a killer UVP (unique value proposition), and the next might be about ways to create a MVP (minimum viable product) for validation purposes.

Collaboration

One of the most important aspects of Ignite is collaboration. ¬†Are you struggling with something as you try to launch your startup? ¬†Do you have any interesting¬†“A-ha” moments you want to share with the group? ¬†We will dedicate plenty of time to help¬†each other¬†out in a collaborative setup.

Accountability

Holding yourself and / or co-founders accountable can be a very difficult task. ¬†We will wrap each meetup with a sprint meeting where Ignite entrepreneurs make goals to hit by the next meetup. ¬†Our goal is to provide you with a little extra motivation to take action and produce results that you can share with the team next month.
how_to_find_us: Please use the entrance on S. Riverside Drive.  There is limited parking available on S. Riverside Drive.  Additional free parking is available in the public lot located on the corner of S. Grove St. and Prairie St.

Every other Friday, we open the Tech Center to non-members. Come check out the new space if you haven't done so already. Bring your laptop and get some work done, or play if you wish. We will be heading out for Tech Lunch at noon. You can find out more details about Tech Lunch, here on Meetup.

name: Tech Lunch
description:
Join us for lunch, conversation and networking this Friday. You can meet at ETC, 73 Riverside Drive, Elgin, by 11:45 on Friday and leave as a group to the restaurant of choice, or you can meet us there. Bring your smile and business cards and join us! Invite a friend or colleague too.


The restaurant for this Meet Up will be announcement about one week prior.

name: ChicagoRuby: Elmhurst - How Do I Build... ?
description:
The "How Do I Build...?" format is somewhere between a hack night and a presentation.

The key question: "How do I build [X] in Ruby or Rails?" We might talk about the best shopping cart or calendar or whatever for Rails. We might talk about the best way to do database maintenance with Ruby, or the best tools for organizing Ruby or Rails development.

Every ChicagoRuby member is invited to drive. Let the group know what you want to do, what you've tried, and what would be interesting to you. Let's put our heads together and create!

Lunch After the Meeting
After most meetings, we go to lunch at the Elmhurst Restaurant, roughly two blocks NW of the meeting venue. Address: 441 West Lake Street, Elmhurst, IL 60126. Join us!

WindyCityThings
Curious about IoT? Master the Internet of Things and make IoT work for you. Details: http://windycitythings.com

WindyCityRails
Level up your skills. WindyCityRails is Chicago's Ruby on Rails conference, happening in September.
Details: http://windycityrails.org

name: Free Coworking Day @ Fox.Build

group.name: Fox.Build - Coworking, Hacking, Maker-Space in St. Charles

description: Bring your laptop, ideas and projects. Come join us and check the place out. A word of warning though, if you are looking for beautiful architecture and serene offices, you probably want to go to the Regus down the street. We are a place where there's bound to be sawdust on the floors. Bring your headset and music, turn it on and do the thing you do the best. We have a fast internet connection, it's walking distance from from great restaurants and coffee shops and perfect for freelancing or people who are sick of the isolation of working from home. Call me if you want to talk about how we can support you and your business. 630-935-4363 Tim

name: Pitch + Catch
description:
Open to the public!

Pitch and Catch offers 25N members an opportunity to present their business plan, new idea, or sales pitch to an audience of mentors, advisors, entrepreneurs, and you!

Pitchers prepare a 5 minute presentation and engage in 20 minutes of feedback and questioning. 25N members gain insight into possible ways they can improve their businesses and gather real time feedback.

The audience learns a great deal from the presentations. There is much to learn every month from these dynamic and diverse entrepreneurs. We need you in our audience!
